content: The Act may be cited as the "Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act, known as the "Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017," defines key terms such as "victim," "surviving spouse," "dependent child," "institution of higher education," and "cost of attendance." The Act defines key terms such as "victim," "surviving spouse," "dependent child," and "institution of higher education." The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 3. TEACHER VICTIM FAMILY ASSISTANCE. The Secretary of Education provides assistance to victims' families, including funeral assistance up to $1,500, a death benefit of $75,000, monthly living assistance for spouses and dependent children, and dependent undergraduate education assistance. Dependent undergraduate education assistance provides an annual amount up to $7,500 or half the total cost of attendance for each dependent child enrolled in a program at an institution of higher education. This assistance does not affect other federal aid under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Dependent child may receive assistance for up to 5 years, contingent on maintaining good standing at the institution. Parental death or remarriage does not impact eligibility for assistance. Tax provisions are introduced for elementary or secondary school staff members killed in an act of violence while performing school duties. Teacher's wages in the year of death are excluded from income under a new section of the Internal Revenue Code. Tax provisions are introduced for elementary or secondary school staff members killed in an act of violence while performing school duties. Any tax on amounts received by the victim's family by reason of school employment is waived for the year of the individual's death. Tax provisions are introduced to exempt income taxes for elementary or secondary school staff members killed in an act of violence while on duty. Additionally, any amount received by the victim's family under the Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017 is excluded from gross income. Tax provisions exempt income taxes for school staff killed in violence while on duty. Amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2016. Teacher Victims' Family Trust Fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code. A trust fund called the Teacher Victims' Family Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States to assist families of teachers who are victims of violence. The fund is financed by an increase in tax revenue from the Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017. Amounts in the Trust Fund will be used for the purposes outlined in the Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017. Additionally, there is an amendment to increase the excise tax on ammunition under Section 4181 of the Internal Revenue Code. The code is amended to include a 13 percent tax on shells and cartridges. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act and the Internal Revenue Code related to the Teacher Victims' Family Assistance Act of 2017. The Teacher Victims' Family Trust Fund amendment will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with a specific provision for articles sold after that date. Additionally, eligibility for public safety officer death benefits is addressed in Section 6. Eligibility for public safety officer death benefits is defined in Section 6 of the Act, stating that victims who die in the line of duty are considered public safety officers, with their surviving spouse and dependent child also recognized as such. Additionally, Section 7 ensures that assistance supplements, rather than replaces, other benefits. Assistance provided under this Act must not replace any benefits or compensation received from the victim's employer, school, government, or insurance coverage.
